review_title: Great Pay, Not Good for someone who likes to be productive
pros: Great pay, benefits, and culture. Good discounts and generally cool to be a part of such an iconic brand. Especially cool to be based at their global headquarters given the campus perks and events.
cons: If you ACTUALLY want to get work done, have some wins/accomplishments under your belt, this is not the place for you. They pride themselves on making decisions by committee, which makes every decision an asinine process. You will spend MONTHS, literally 6+ months "socializing" an idea or body of work, and then have something come in and just render it a moot point. You just wasted 6 months doing literally nothing that matters. But, hey, you got paid well. They are trying to brand themselves internally as a technology company, yet they don't even have the MOST BASIC technology capabilities. It's truly a joke. And people push back on technological progress. The leadership they have on the tech side don't seem to know what the hell they're doing or they're just heavily influenced away from doing the smart thing. Several people doing the same job. So much overlap. Not uncommon to join a meeting and find that someone else on the call has your exact same job and now you two have to battle it out to figure out who's going to take this one on or what part of it you'll work on. They could probably let go of 60% of the people that work here and you'd still never notice.

review_title: No Development, No Empathy, Pay Relative to other Big Name Retail Brands is LOW
pros: $450 Stipend upon hire to buy anything in the store as your Staff Dress Great Discount 40%, Lifetime discount after 5 years of service Every 6 weeks Staff Dress window to buy product at 60% discount for stores, 50% for outlets Great Benefits if Full-Time : Health, Vision, Dental, 401K, Employee Stock Purchase Program, many more Customers and Employees are the similar types of fun, active, sport/culture loving people Events and Experiences at the stores are really fun You can shop the Employee store in Oregon You get a chance to access hard-to-get sneakers through raffles
cons: Employees regularly (every 6 weeks) encouraged to buy their own Staff Dress, it is not provided, you must obviously exclusively wear Nike, you end up spending a chunk of your check back on Nike Benefits not as accessible if Part-Time, Healthcare benefits are expensive for Part-Timers Seasonal for the first 90 days, so you're basically Full-time without the benefits Even as a part-timer you're getting scheduled 30-40 hours a week Claim to work with availability but you must have a lot of availability, and it isn't easy to fit in school, another job, your family, people's kids, etc Even the best workers are hardly developed by Managers Just enough staff to not fall apart, not enough staff to run ideally, Managers are too busy to help you map out your goals, everyone is too drained Pay is so bad for the amount of traffic and people you're expected to provide world-class service to, even Managers complain about the pay being too low; they genuinely talk about asking higher-ups to raise everybody's pay but it never comes You are always around brand-new shiny product, it entices you to spend your money back on Nike, which you do whether you love it or hate it At the end of the day, there is always that feeling that Nike really isn't doing that much to be ethical or sustainable, even though it claims to be. Nike is not B-Corp Certified.

review_title: Large company with some great teams, and other not-so-great teams
job_title: Embedded Systems Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: * I was on a wonderful team with an extremely caring manager, reasonably caring teammates, and many wonderful opportunities to sharpen my engineering skills in a company that probably isn't widely known for its engineers * The social atmosphere, especially prior to COVID-19, was fantastic and made it very easy to unwind between intense weeks of crunching toward a product launch or a feature launch * Pay was decent for the Portland, Oregon metropolitan area, and expectations for promotions, pay increases, and things of that sort were clear.
cons: * As an engineer in an innovation department, it didn't feel like there was a whole lot of respect for the engineering side of the department. Footwear designers and similar always seemed to be the stars of the show, even when they didn't do a whole lot to achieve whatever is being hyped up * Nike, fundamentally speaking, is a company caught at the crossroads of being a traditional footwear and apparel company, a modern fashion company, and supposedly a technology company. Quite frankly, and despite some gems such as Tom Clarke and similar, the lack of technical, future-ready leadership willing to really push the company in the right direction ends up directly affecting anyone in the company who is a part of a team that focuses on engineering (whether that be hardware or software) new products. Given how stagnant some of the technological teams of Nike are, I personally wouldn't call it a technology company.

review_title: Great place to work, A little out of touch
pros: *healthy budgets for projects *leadership decent, easy chart your own path if not *values-driven, apparent internally and externally *growth trajectory for most roles *genuine care for employee well-being *ability to work with legendary people externally
cons: *bloated, many layers of hierarchy and competing geos that makes getting work done tricky *the marketing indoctrination is very effective, internally as much as externally :/ not all ideas are good ideas ! *out of touch with modern digital practices. usually slow to adopt, often leaving them delayed in cultural connection, left in the dust and talking to themselves. most folks who run these platforms are older in their careers and hiring agencies to do the work - this is true of most marketing projects *a place to “finish” your career - as a young person you will not be taken seriously until you inevitably conform to all the things that everyone else at the company tells you to do. helpful for your career success, detrimental for your creativity if you follow the advice.

review_title: Nike is an enjoyable place to work, but opportunities to advance can be limited
pros: Nike's best attribute are it's people. They are chock-full of diverse and passionate people that are largely very supportive of each other and the work that they are doing.
cons: The biggest con of working at Nike is the lack of advancement opportunities outside of working at the company HQ in Oregon. If you're not willing to move to OR, you will most likely not go far with the company.

job_title: Retail Sales Associate in Jackson, NJ
pros: -30 %discount in Jackson outlet, nj 40% off from online as well as other Nike stores -1 hr lunch break -fun coworkers -not much of a difference switching from part time to full time unless you would like to rank your way up to coach/head-coach/ specialist etc. -for life discount after 5 years employment -discount at converse
cons: -minimum pay of 15/ 15.50 per hr -benefits for health and medical are not worth it and will take your paycheck -terrible management as they come and go within the past two years- over 4 different managers fired -unreliable management -managers schedule on your off days and won't communicate with employees what is best for them or be clear with their intentions -managers talk bad about employees as well as other managers -managers have breached Nike policy rules by reselling and profiting from discounts -biweekly

pros: 1) If you are determined to live in the Portland area, Nike is probably one of the better local employers to work for. 2) The brand is well-recognized, so having Nike on the resume can help secure interviews at good companies down the road.
cons: It seems like the company lost a lot of top talent due to mandatory back-to-office. Teams are siloed and don't work well together. Regular reorgs make it difficult to gain momentum. The culture is fairly passive-aggressive, ego-driven, and cult-like. The people who succeed here are those that drink the kool-aid, talk in sweeping generalizations, and become comfortable in stagnation. I left after 6 months. For context, I have 10 years of experience across half a dozen Fortune 500 retail companies.

pros: Pros There is no doubt that this is a company that is disrupting the traditional job marketplace. You get out, what you put in. We are encouraged to lean on one another. I feel well supported and I'm fully invested in the direction that this company is moving towards. Cons I can honestly and truthfully say, there is nothing. You get out what you put into this job/company. Glassdoor offers so much ability to grow, connect, and disrupt!
cons: Cons Some teething issues with our new campaign product but I’m sure we will get through it as we always do. I feel like csms have too many competing priorities with sales and too many targets in general.

pros: Nike truly invests into those who want to grow within and pursue a career with Nike whether that's in the retail setting or corporate setting.
cons: We don't have employee access to the sneakers app. Meaning if we want the newest Jordan sneakers we have to join the same raffle the whole US enters. Aside from that no other cons to mention

pros: Great location at the outlets.
cons: Hostility from managers was the hardest part of navigating the job. There was not much training but management expected 110% of everyone while new hires received very little knowledge of how things were run.

pros: Being a part of the Nike retail family is ok at best. The employee discount is the main pro of working here. It's definitely not a difficult job to do by any means. Usually, all your other co-workers(athletes) are enthusiastic and have a soft spot for the brand. At my store, there's constant discussion over designs of shoes or apparel and you can tell there is a genuine interest in the company.
cons: Usually, the managers take into account your availability. Most of our hired athletes are full-time students so that obviously takes priority. Once submitting the availability sheet, the manager reviews it and makes your schedule based on the days you can work for the most part. Come holiday time or any busy quarter for the company the availability sheets are disregarded and you get scheduled on days you can't work. After your initial hiring period, you can receive a bonus after one year, and so on. These bonuses were once acceptable but now they've been reduced to about .50 to .75 cents. After being with the company for a while I would hope they see the work that we athletes put into maintaining the store and keeping up with sales yet this is no incentive.

job_title: Machine Operator in Saint Charles, MO
pros: Benefits and pto accrual are the main benefits and why I have stayed.
cons: The lack of communication is astounding. The supervisors and management do not communicate too the production floor at all for day to day operations. When I first started here there were many perks and moral boosters I was very impressed. Over the last 3-4 years our facility in Saint Charles has been taking those perks away . For instance they used to give us meals for special events from like sugar fire or a local Italian restaurant. But now we get hot dogs with stale buns, a single chicken leg that I only take one bite out of cause it tastes horrible, or cold corn dogs. But all of us production crew get to watch the office workers and supervisors still get those nicer meals brought in for them instead of downgraded café food. The way supervisors and management treat the production floor is like how a horrible parent tears and talks down to their children for just being children.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Beaverton, OR
pros: Great people, master class in branding, fun environment. Good benefits and decent pay… if you climb the ladder for years there is really great pay. I also had a nice boss that helped me take “stretch roles” to stay interested, which helped immensely.
cons: Tech side of biz work on an entirely different campus and feels disconnected from rest of business. Really difficult to make the switch to a different role or move up, especially if you are an admin or in retail (which is where all the diversify is, go figure). Management typically prefers to find external new hires for bragging rights. Often roles are taken by contractors, especially towards end of fiscal year, which limits opportunities. Heard this has improved since I left. Pay is definitely lower than in other industries, due to Nike “glamour tax”. Most roles require you to live near Beaverton, even if remote, to justify expense/experience of the campus.

When I interviewed for this role, I shared that I would accept a position at Nike if I was allowed the opportunity to also serve as a consultant who will have a voice in design decisions, and not just as a developer who will simply be seen as an order taker. I made this request because, as a senior instructional designer and e-learning developer with over 15 years experience, I need to be able to exercise some level of independence based on my extensive background in the field. The hiring manager agreed with what I was seeking and raised no concerns with my request. I was quickly offered the position shortly afterward. 

However, once I was brought on board, not only did I not get a proper introduction to the rest of my team, but I was immediately thrown into a mountain of work without the appropriate amount of time needed to gather and review the necessary content from SMEs and properly develop the course material. This problem has persisted for several projects throughout my time here and has contributed to work-life balance issues. Whenever I inquire about the rationale for the aggressive timelines that management had set, I am simply ignored or told there is nothing that can be done. To make matters worse, management insists on micromanaging every design decision, which often leads to chaotic and rushed development. This is something I have never experienced anywhere else in my career.

Due to management’s poor project management skills, they end up sabotaging our team's ability to be creative, independent, and meet client deadlines. Even though management has admitted that they lack the technical skills needed to assist us with the development of online training, they refuse to rely on more knowledgeable team members to help inform more realistic project timelines based on their development experience. As a result, we have often let down several clients and have lost several ETWs due to being burned out or scared away. Meanwhile, the reason given to others for the high turnover in our team is typically not based on truth (e.g. health reasons, personal family matters). 

If you are considering a position like this one in the organization (whether as an FTE or ETW), please take the time to ask critical questions to help you make an informed decision. Ask about the team’s turnover rate, project deadlines, and whether you will have a meaningful voice in design decisions. If the responses you receive are vague or sound like lip service, that should be a red flag and your cue to look elsewhere.

review_title: Great if you work in the right group
pros: Some good benefits - discounted product, lots of PTO once you've put in a few years, ESPP and profit share/match are great.  Great child care centers.  Flexible work hours and telecommuting available.  Lots of lip service to work/life balance - in the right group you may even experience it (I do).  Casual atmosphere and culture.
cons: Big company with lots of office politics and excessive meetings.  Seems like you have to be an athletic white male to have a good chance of promotion to upper management (not a lot of women and minorities up there).  Communication is talked about a lot, but not followed through well (Case in point - tons of construction on campus right now, and close to zero communication to employees on the plans.  Everything we know about the construction plans has come from external newspapers. Hopefully we'll get some info before the buildings are open, but I won't hold my breath.)  Annual ("merit") salary increases barely keep up with inflation (for most of us, anyway... EVP's and above seem to be making out ok).

pros: The benefit of possibly gaining equity in Nike stock.
cons: Working in material design is extremely strenuous. Not only do you need to have a full understanding of all types of textiles/leathers/plastics, you also need to have the eye of a creative designer – which comes last. As a materials designer you are mostly a developer and engineer. You will make the same salary as a color designer, who only has to drop colors from a predetermined palette into some lineart, to be passed to you to complete with full material specifications, including how sustainable the product will be, how much it will cost to make, and how it can be manufactured. There is an IMMENSE difference in design functions at Nike. A material designer gets pittance in salary, yet does the absolute most technical work. A material designer at this company is not a designer, but a technical developer. Nike has no room for promotions. In order to reach a better position and paygrade it's required you apply for a new position on a new team.

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: You get a discount on overpriced merchandise
cons: "I am not telling you to work overtime, but we expect it!" - Nike Manager Nike is full of charlatans! Don't trust the recruiting department. They will say anything to get you to come work for Nike. I fell for it and it cost me. The environment is unwelcoming. Management is cold. Team culture is toxic. I watched adults tattling on others just to get a gold star from the "boss". It was like working with a bunch of elitist toddlers. Throwing markers and screaming is a common practice among stressed-out team members. I used to think it was only specific to the team I was on until I moved to a couple of other teams. It is a Nike problem. Managers have no respect for personal time, and you'll be contacted nights and weekends. It feels like working for a company in the early 2000s. No direction and everyone is just throwing buzzwords around instead of trying to solve business problems. You'd think a company with Nike's reputation wouldn't have these types of issues. I watch managers take roll. I watched a manager drive his team into the ground, lay them off because they didn't deliver, and do it again to another team. At some point, Nike needs to purge the bad actors, but I have seen how it is a good ole boys club and they protect their own. I know this comes across as an axe to grind. However, I am only trying to save someone from the emotional and mental strain that Nike will have on you. I didn't believe some of the bad reviews, yet here I am writing one. In doing a quick search you'll see that Nike has been guilty of much worse.

review_title: Embrace challenges, stay positive, and have fun
job_title: Senior Solutions Analyst in Portland, OR
pros:
Nike is a growth company constantly changing to meet the marketplace and employees' needs. There are many opportunities to make an impact and be challenged. You have to search for the possibilities; don't expect opportunities to be handed to you. The best advice I received when I started was to 'bloom where I'm planted.'

The WHQ campus is a fun place to work, and Nike puts a lot of thought and effort into giving us an inspirational work environment.

Nike embraces many forms of diversity; you can find support to help you be your best self, including company benefits.
cons:
Nike is unlike any other company I've worked at, and there are a few areas that initially look like "Cons" but are opportunities to sharpen skills. 

For example, the matrix organizational structure with decentralized authority and management presents the most challenges for people. Much depends on leaders' understanding of how to influence and make change within the company matrix. A deficiency here can lead to an unsatisfying experience. My advice is to hold on; it will change eventually. My recommendation is to make friends with people you 'gel' with who are focused on long-term change, avoid the echo chamber, and are good stewards of company resources without a side agenda.

cons:
- It is a fast-paced work environment and the demand can be extremely stressfull and overwhelming. 
- There is a global need to streamline and collaborate on projects to work efficiently and save time spent on Zoom meetings.

pros: The projects you work on are of high quality, budgets are high, and the talent in the weeds you work side-by-side with are excellent at what they do each in their own way. Luxurious work lifestyle. Salary and benefits are very good. Diversity and gender equity is the best I've seen at any company - and they are doing the work. There are some great people within the toxic culture which gives hope to the environment changing in the future.
cons: Ego. A very privileged workforce that lacks empathy for each other and is quick to judge without taking time to understand nor help each other succeed. Many unspoken internal rules that are opposite of the brand mission. Constant guessing of what leadership says vs what management expects. That leads to constant internal confusion. Very little organization, toxic optimism, no consistency, little to no onboarding, no support for success, poor management, very bad communication, too many meetings, terrible time & resource management, a culture that retaliates, all the isms, good ole' boys network even with so many female workers and a renewed focus on equity in leadership. Lots of high level good intentions, very little governance with management and little follow through so issues you've heard about from years ago persist and you see great people get passed by or pushed out based on petty attitudes from an old-school corporate way of managing. FTE workers have little to no work-life balance therefore expectations of ETW and contractors vary widely depending on the attitude towards them.

review_title: Why working at Nike is 4 stars.
job_title: Part Time Athlete in New York, NY
pros: Nike has the best benefits. They put their employees first, well corporate does but, I'll get to that soon. The company is quite innovative in the products that they create and sell to the public. Also, they will remind you that they aren't just a retail brand company but, they are a brand for the people. They host events that consist of trial running, community building, sponsoring youth basketball and the list goes further. Aside from the media issues they face, internally I know the mission is for a good cause and that's why I enjoyed working for the company. This will/was my last retail job and I enjoyed my time.
cons: The only issues I've faced working at the company is coaches/athletes taking things personal as opposed to not understanding business optics. I was thrown into being a manager for another popular footwear company at a young age and I've seen what it was like to take things personal and not understand the business optics. So for myself to come into a new environment and see managers that were in their position for many years not make decisions based off business but based off emotions. It definitely lacked chemistry within the department I was in. Also, a lot of operational moves that seemed a bit shady because they felt some of their decisions were best for the business but, for the in-store employees, we were affected due to lack of spacing for new product and communication. It just felt like things weren't in control but aside from that, I did not have any problems.

review_title: Company has excellent morals, management is political
pros: Working for Nike was wonderful in a larger picture sense. The company has a strong moral foundation publicly that I aligned with and it made me proud to say I worked there. There was a lot of room for growth and movement if you're willing to relocate. Opportunity to flex into a WHQ role short term (again, if you're willing to relocate). Lots of tools/resources for personal development.
cons:
Your experience in a store will depend 100% on what managers are in that store. District managers allow store managers who are unqualified and bad at their jobs to continue to manage with little to no supervision. Very few channels to safely express concerns. Retaliation is a real possibility that upper management things could never happen. HR will take the store managers work above yours every time. The company puts an emphasis on work-life balance, but this only extends to WHQ employees. They expect store management to have open availability, work overtime at request, and will discriminate against you if you have children or outside restrictions that prevent you from working more than 40 hour when requested. As a regular store employee, they expected you to have extremely flexible availability in an effort to hire less employees but then at times would only be able to offer you 14 hours of work. You'd be unable to have a second job because of the availability requirements, but also wouldn't get enough hours to support yourself. Favoritism and nepotism are in abundance. Again - if you're in a store with good management, the experience will be wonderful. If you're in a store with poor management, it will be awful.

There's also rampant sexism among upper level leadership (territory managers, district managers, store managers). I'm sure not all districts/territories/stores are like this but mine absolutely was.

review_title: The Juice is not worth the squeeze
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros:
- Looks good on resume
- 50% discount at company store
- Okay benefits
cons:
- No work life balance: In my group you have to work 12h+ a day to keep your head above water. This lasted for more than a year with no end in sight until I quit.
- 'Who you know' is way more important than 'what you know'. While this is true for any big company it is especially true for Nike. Forget about working hard, here you need to have connections to get ahead. 
- Very disorganized place - sometimes you ask yourself how can this be a successful multi-billion dollar company. 
- Little to no support for new employees - a few hours of 'knowledge transfer' and you on your own.
- Enormous turnover - a revolving door of people coming and going.
- The way ETWs are treated as second class citizens and given false hopes that one day they may be converted. Contracting agencies are more to blame for that but Nike is turning a blind eye so they can lure more people in.
- The so called 'Leadership' is very weak, ineffective and quite frankly self serving

job_title: Global Product Manager in Beaverton, OR
pros: Fun campus, great opportunities, exciting projects
cons: Culture isn't what it used to be. Really easy to burn out. If you're considering working at Nike, take care in interviewing the team you'll work with to ensure that it is the best environment for your mental health.

pros:
- The Company does offer great benefits and perks.
- Exciting projects to work on
- There are great people who care about the brand, the people and the work that we do.
cons:
- Massive re-orgs and layoffs every 12-18 months that impact 1000+ people.
- Role and responsibility changes due to layoffs, forcing people into jobs that they do not want to do and changing the direction of their careers at Nike.
- No career building regardless of what they promise.
- Work load went from 65+ hours for 10 months to 30 hours for 2 months of the year.
- Employees are nothing more than a number due to the size of the Company.
- They have large amounts of ETW (Contract workers) that are business critical but are treated like second class citizens who spend years working as ETWs in hopes to get hired hired on as full time FTEs.
- So many of the benefits and perks offered go unused since most people don't know what is available to them.
- Moral bobs up and down like a yoyo throughout the year leaving large groups of people feeling unmotivated and unappreciated.
- Some Managers are horrible at their jobs and should not be allowed to manage. 
- There are lot of BIG egos that clash on a regular basis making for an awkward work life.

pros: Nike has a great history and standing in the public eye. Great benefits.
cons: But inside the factory, the culture is toxic. The Directors and higher ups have great intentions for implementing great programs and improving the workers way of life. But the follow-through that is supposed to be implemented by the factory management is non-existent. They will quietly, continue to do things their way. Too many times, have managers/supervisors done less than the bare minimum for their direct reports. One example, CFE 1:1's have a standard of one every quarter, should take anywhere from 15-60 mins. One supervisor will make sure to get them done in a timely manner and actually has a conversation with their direct reports. And another will boast that they can get 15 CFE's done in 13 minutes... Literally less than 1 minute per person. It's extremely inconsistent and inconsiderate. To the point that the workers feel stifled and cut off at the knees at this company. There is no room for growth. And the supervisors do not make it a priority to develop their personnel. To top it off, if someone were to report or say something, they are retaliated against by having the limited opportunities removed from their path for growth. Then proceed to be faced with microaggressions until they inevitably decided to part ways with the company.

review_title: No doubt depends on the part of the company you work in, but my experience has been phenomenal
pros: I work with wonderful people who are both driven and caring. Management goes out of their way to emphasize the importance of work-life balance, and seems to genuinely mean it. Despite the various scandals Nike has been embroiled in over the last 5 years or so, I cannot think of a less sexist-feeling environment. The majority of leaders around me are strong, confident women, well-respected by their male and female colleagues alike, who aren't afraid to speak frankly and unapologetically about their priorities outside of work, which, as a new mom myself, I've been very grateful for. Great benefits as well, which keep getting better (though some more PTO would always be nice).
cons: The way the 2020 reorg was handled was annoying, to say the least. An attempt at transparency backfired when incomplete information left us more questioning/paranoid than we might have been otherwise, for months. The changes that were made were then hardly explained, resulting in a lot of confusion. Short of that, I'm not sure any complaints I have are unique to Nike so much as the inevitable result of an organization this huge. My area of the company is still in its infancy, relatively speaking, so there are a lot of uncharted processes we're trying to figure out and navigating the "matrix" to get things done can be a nightmare, recent "simplication" (AKA reorg) notwithstanding.

review_title: Not A Good Place for Parents, Especially Mothers
pros:
Competitive placement in the market.
Cult following that leads to quite a bit of stability for the company.
cons:
- Being denied maternity leave benefits. I was granted short term disability and that was it. No parental leave, no salary top up, no pre-birth medical leave, no guarantee of return to position. I asked if I could take some PTO before giving birth and the response from HR was I could, but then that would lower the amount of time I could take for the baby. I was counting how leave I had by the days. Three months after my son was born and 3.5 months after I left Nike for a company that instantly granted me full maternity leave for 4.5 months at full pay, I was still getting notices of denial of benefits from Nike.

 - Repaying a sign on bonus and 8 months later still having back and forth to update taxes. Hence, the reminder that I should leave a review on GlassDoor so that others have a heads up on what they're walking into.

 - I'd lay out a long laundry list around management, HR, toxic work culture where one team routinely takes credit for another team's work and bogs the other team down with external consultants, but they are just all the small things that add up to where being denied maternity leave benefits was not unexpected.

I had heard about Nike's poor treatment of mothers before joining and asked about it in the interview process. The responses I received were encouraging that they had completely revamped the process and added additional support. However, the support just isn't there. If you are pregnant at Nike and in the corporate headquarters, find the Slack channel where mothers are helping other mothers. The tricks folks are using are reminiscent of the 1980's, pre-FMLA.

For context, if Nike tried to treat me this way - there's no one I believe would be immune to a denial of benefits. This is not a company difference between hourly and salary or junior and senior. While there I also saw another very senior pregnant woman's role vanish when she went on leave. For men, to the best of my knowledge, benefits are 8 weeks and you have to work at Nike a full year before being eligible. I had to work with so many men who couldn't keep their eyes open in meetings, because they were exhausted.
